facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 298 of 1973 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 298 of 1973.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Decree dated 26th May 1971 of Delhi High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. O.S. 16 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Decree dated the 26th May, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No.  O.S. 16 of 1970 .

facts.text: Land leased to plaintiff from 1-4-1931 for 90 years at annual rent Rs. 365/- by Secretary of State for India.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondent had sued for a declaration that the annual rent of Rs. 365/- payable on a piece of land situated in Basti Ara Kashan, Paharganj, New Delhi, leased to him from 1-4-31 for a period of 90 years

facts.text: Premium of Rs. 18,054/- paid for the lease.

anchor.surface_text: on behalf of the Secretary of State for India companyld number be enhanced during the subsistence of the lease for the grant of which he had paid a premium of Rs. 18,054/-.

facts.text: Land situated in Basti Ara Kashan, Paharganj, New Delhi, measuring 5444 square yards.

anchor.surface_text: the annual rent of Rs. 365/- payable on a piece of land situated in Basti Ara Kashan, Paharganj, New Delhi, leased to him from 1-4-31 for a period of 90 years

facts.text: Land management entrusted to Delhi Improvement Trust, then to Delhi Development Authority after abolition of DIT in 1957 under Section 60 of Delhi Development Act 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The plot of land leased was entrusted for management on behalf of the Government of India to the Delhi improvement Trust, and, thereafter, after the abolition of the Delhi Improvement Trust in 1957, to the Delhi Development Authority under Section 60 of the Delhi Development Act of 1957.

facts.text: Rs. 5,935.25 retrospectively demanded and realised as arrears of enhanced rent from 1.1.52 to 30.6.63 after warrant of arrest dated 2.6.64.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff also claimed refund of Rs. 5,935.25 ps. which had been retrospectively demanded and realised from him as arrears of enhanced rent from 1.1.52to 30.6.63 after issuing a warrant of arrest dated 2.6.64 against him.

facts.text: Plaintiff prayed for injunction restraining appellant from realising rent excess of Rs. 365/- during lease.

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, the Plaintiff prayed for an injunction to restrain the appellant, acting on behalf of the lessor, from realising an annual rent in excess of Rs. 365/- for the duration of the lease

facts.text: Lease deed Ex. P2 dated 17-9-1931 between Secretary of State for India and lessee.

facts.text: Defendants admitted in para 1 of written statement that lease commencing 1-4-31 was for 90 years.

anchor.surface_text: the assertion, in paragraph 1 of the plaint, that the lease companymencing on, 1-4-31 was for the term of 90 years, is admitted to be companyrect in paragraph 1 of the replies on merits in the written statement

facts.text: Defendants did not admit that rent of Rs. 365/- could not be enhanced within 90 years.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, number admitted by the defendants. that the yearly ground rent of Rs. 365/- companyld number be enhanced within a period of 90 years.

facts.text: Real dispute: whether deed dated 17-9-31 provides for rent enhancement within 90 years via covenants 9 and 10, or only on fresh lease after 90 years.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 4 of the joint written statement of the defendants shows that the real dispute between the parties was whether the deed dated 17-9-31, under which the lease companymenced from 1-4-3 1, provided for an enhancement

facts.text: Plaintiff asserted in para 12 plaint: lease for 90 years at Rs. 365/-, rent cannot be enhanced during term.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 12 of the plaint, the plaintiff asserted That according to, the terms of the Lease dated 17th September, 1931 the land has been leased to the plaintiff for a term of 90 years at the rate of rent of Rs. 365/- per year.

facts.text: Defendants in para 12 WS: lease for 90 years subject to renewal at enhanced rate per lease terms.

anchor.surface_text: The reply in the written statement in paragraph 12 on merits was That para 12 of the amended plaint is number admitted as stated. The lease dated 17th September, 1931, was granted to the plaintiff for a total period of 90 years

facts.text: Delhi High Court single judge dismissed suit on merits.

anchor.surface_text: These questions were decided against the defendants by a learned judge of the Delhi High Court, who tried the case and dismissed the suit on merits, as well as by the Division Bench which had allowed the plaintiffs appeal

facts.text: Delhi High Court Division Bench allowed plaintiff's appeal and decreed suit on merits.

anchor.surface_text: as well as by the Division Bench which had allowed the plaintiffs appeal and decreed by the suit on merits.

facts.text: Supreme Court held rent cannot be enhanced during initial 90 years; enhancement only on renewal after 90 years.

anchor.surface_text: We think that companyvenant No. 9 operates only at the end of the terms of 90 years because it says so.

holdings.text: Covenant No. 9 of the lease deed operates only at the end of the term of 90 years and does not permit enhancement of rent during the subsistence of the initial 90-year lease.

anchor.surface_text: We think that covenant No. 9 operates only at the end of the terms of 90 years because it says so. The problem of interpreting the proviso was solved by the Division Bench largely by giving the word with,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal construction of covenant 9 referring to 'term hereby granted' as 90 years; renewal only at end; cannot coexist with intra-term renewals; harmonious reading avoids absurdity.

holdings.text: The proviso to covenant No. 9 suffers from uncertainty and its ambiguous words can be disregarded, allowing the clear words of demise for 90 years to prevail.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the proviso to covenant No. 9 could be said to suffer from the vice of an uncertainty which can only be removed by ignoring the words creating this uncertainty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso unclear on 'original term'; leads to absurdity if applied to 90-year term; exception in grants construed favorably to grantee if uncertain.

holdings.text: The rule construing grants by the Sovereign favorably to the Sovereign and against the subject is a feudal relic inapplicable in modern democratic India, especially where valuable consideration is paid.

anchor.surface_text: We doubt whether a lease granted by the Secretary of State for India even before 1950 could be interpreted today by relying upon any special rule of construction applicable to leases by, or on behalf of the British Sovereign.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-Constitution India rejects feudal prerogatives; State has superior bargaining power; even English rule relaxed for valuable consideration; ordinary rules apply.

holdings.text: The Division Bench's decree declaring no rent enhancement during 90 years, refund of excess, and injunction is affirmed; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, affirm the decision and decree of the Division Bench, and dismiss this appeal with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease deed interpreted as whole under standard rules yields single coherent meaning favoring 90-year fixed rent term.

holdings.text: Estoppel against enhancement not considered as plaintiff did not rely on it despite stating facts.

anchor.surface_text: As the plaintiff had not relied upon an estoppel even though facts, which may give rise to it, were stated, that question need not be considered by us here.

Lord Wensleydale in Monypenny v. Monypenny 1  said the question is number what the parties to a deed may have intended to do by entering into that deed, but what is the meaning of the words used in that deed a most important distinction in all cases of companystruction and the disregards of which often leads to erroneous companyclusions.

precedents.cited_holding: the question is number what the parties to a deed may have intended to do by entering into that deed, but what is the meaning of the words used in that deed

anchor.surface_text: Brett, L.J., in Re Meredith, ex p. Chick 2  observed I am disposed to follow the rule of companystruction which was laid down by Lord Denman and Baron Parke They said that in companystruing instruments you must have, regard. number to the presumed intention of the parties, but to the meaning of the words which they have used.

precedents.cited_proposition: Regard meaning of words used, not presumed intention
precedents.cited_holding: in companystruing instruments you must have, regard. number to the presumed intention of the parties, but to the meaning of the words which they have used

Bina Das Gupta and Others v. Sachindra Mohan Das Gunta 7 , where the following statement of law in Stavill Eros., Ltd. v. Bethell 8  , by Sterling J., was cited with approval by this Court

precedents.cited_proposition: Earlier words prevail over later inconsistency

precedents.citation: Smt. Bina Das Gupta and Others v. Sachindra Mohan Das Gunta 7

anchor.surface_text: He also relied on Smt. Bina Das Gupta and Others v. Sachindra Mohan Das Gunta 7 , where the following statement of law in Stavill Eros., Ltd. v. Bethell 8  , by Sterling J., was cited with approval by this Court It is a settled rule of companystruction that where there is a grant and an exception out of it, the exception is to be taken  1   1861  9 H. L. C. 114 at p. 146.

precedents.case_name: Bina Das Gupta v Sachindra Mohan Das Gunta
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule of construction for grants and exceptions

anchor.surface_text: where the following statement of law in Stavill Eros., Ltd. v. Bethell 8  , by Sterling J., was cited with approval by this Court It is a settled rule of companystruction that where there is a grant and an exception out of it, the exception is to be taken as inserted for the benefit of the grantor and to be companystrued in favour of the grantee.

precedents.cited_proposition: Exception in grant construed in favour of grantee; if uncertain, exception fails
precedents.cited_holding: where there is a grant and an exception out of it, the exception is to be taken as inserted for the benefit of the grantor and to be companystrued in favour of the grantee. If then the grant be clear, but the exception be so framed as to be, bad for uncertainty, it appears to us that on this principle the grant is operative and the exception fails.

precedents.citation: Glyn and Ors. v. Margetson Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent also relied on the following passsage from Glyn and Ors. v. Margetson Co. 1  in the judgment of Lords Halsbury Looking at the whole of the instrument, and seeing that one must regard, for a reason which I will give in a moment, as its main purpose, one must reject words, indeed whole provisions, if they are inconsistent with what one assumes to be the main purpose of the companytract.

precedents.cited_proposition: Reject words inconsistent with main purpose of contract
precedents.cited_holding: Looking at the whole of the instrument... one must reject words, indeed whole provisions, if they are inconsistent with what one assumes to be the main purpose of the companytract.

anchor.surface_text: We may also cite here Raja Rajendira Chand v. Simt.Sukhi 1  where it was pointed out that the English rule a grant should be companystrued most favourably to the Sovereign was subject to the exception that, in cases of grants made for valuable companysideration, as is the position in the lease before us, the Sovereigns honour must take precedence over the Sovereigns profit.

precedents.case_name: Raja Rajendira Chand v Smt Sukhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Grants by Sovereign for valuable consideration construed in favour of grantee
precedents.cited_holding: in cases where the grant is for valuable companysideration, it is companystrued in favour of the grantee, for the honour of the Sovereign

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, affirm the decision and decree of the Division Bench, and dismiss this appeal with costs.
